Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: You just realized a comment you made has deeply hurt your I04iend's feelings, and you need to call them right now to apologize and clear the air.
Story: It’s Saturday evening, and I’m sprawled on my bed, phone in hand. I see a text from Mom: “Hope you’re having a good weekend! Miss you.” I know she expects me to check in, even if it’s just a quick call or a few texts. I haven’t replied since yesterday, and guilt pricks at me. At the same time, my phone buzzes with a message from my friend, Jamie. The words sting: “I can’t believe you said that. I thought you understood me.” My heart sinks. I realize my joke earlier wasn’t funny to Jamie—it hurt them. I need to call and apologize, to explain myself and fix things before it gets worse. But Mom’s waiting, probably worrying, and I promised I’d be better at keeping in touch. My thumb hovers over the call button, torn between reaching out to my mom or Jamie first. The weight of both expectations presses down on me, and I can’t shake the feeling that, no matter what I do next, I’ll be letting someone down.
